title: 112_s3084
content: The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" is the short title of the Act. It deals with the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends Subchapter I of chapter 73 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new section on Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary shall organize the Veterans Health Administration into 12 geographically defined networks aligned with the Department's mission and national goals, ensuring integrated healthcare systems. The VISN Reorganization Act of 2012 establishes 12 Veterans Integrated Service Networks to align with the Department's mission. These networks are responsible for forming alliances with various healthcare organizations, managing regional budgets, implementing national metrics for healthcare delivery, and ensuring high-quality clinical programs and services. The VISN Reorganization Act of 2012 establishes 12 Veterans Integrated Service Networks to align with the Department's mission. These networks are responsible for forming alliances with healthcare organizations, managing regional budgets, implementing national metrics for healthcare delivery, and ensuring high-quality clinical programs and services. The Secretary ensures reduction of duplicate functions and promotes collaboration among the networks and other entities for effective patient care, education, and research. The Secretary considers various offices for collaboration, including Department of Defense, Coast Guard, State and local agencies, medical schools, Congress, emergency preparedness organizations, community and faith-based organizations, and other Federal Government offices. The Secretary ensures that Veterans Integrated Service Networks develop and share innovations and best practices. Each network has one headquarters co-located with a VA medical center, with limited staff. Annual reports on employment are submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The report includes details on the number of individuals employed at each headquarters of a Veterans Integrated Service Network, positions at the headquarters and those not located there, and the budget impact. Additionally, a triennial review and reassessment of the structure is required every three years. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks' structure and operations, submitting recommendations to improve them to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. This includes combining specific networks like VISN 1, VISN 2, and VISN 3 into one network, and VISN 4 and VISN 5 into another. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 10, 11, 12, 15, 23, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 22 will be combined into fewer networks as part of the consolidation efforts by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 10, 11, 12, 15, 23, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 22 will be consolidated into a single network. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will retain one headquarters for each set of consolidated networks and eliminate any additional headquarters to meet requirements. Measures will be taken to find new positions for individuals affected by the elimination of headquarters. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will relocate headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks to be co-located with medical centers or find new positions for affected individuals. An implementation plan must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may renew or enter into a new lease to maintain headquarters in the current location, with a report required to be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing reasons for the lease decision, underutilized buildings in medical centers, and lease costs. The current lease details include the annual rent amount, total cost, and square footage being leased. The new lease cost and square footage to be leased are also provided. SEC. 3. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary shall establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will evaluate finance operations, compliance activities, and outreach efforts to veterans who served in specific military operations. The Secretary will establish regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. This includes assessing programs for women veterans, addressing homelessness among veterans, energy consumption, and other relevant operations. Staff may be hired as needed, and centers will be co-located with Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers. The Secretary may choose a location for a regional support center that is not co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center, but must submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs explaining the reasons. The report should include a list of underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network, the cost of the lease if engaged, and other relevant details. The Secretary must transfer employees from headquarters to regional support centers for initial staffing. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the title. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not require any changes in the location or type of medical care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
